7.68.text: I've been an artist for 20-odd years

12.07.text:
and I'm going to tell you a little bit about
my experiences

16.93.text:
going out to Helmand in February 2010 
on [Operation] HERRICK 11,

22.43.text: primarily based with the Green Howards -

30.58.text: As an artist I've covered a diversity of subjects,

34.13.text:
from auction houses to Indian fishermen to
the African diaspora in Scotland.

44.26.text:
However, never in all my years 
did I consider that

47.46.text:
one day I would be drawing away 
in a pitched battle

51.74.text: with the smoke, the dust, the blasts,

54.15.text:
the clatter of machine guns and the sort of
sounds going all around me.

59.78.text:
It would have been something similar that
my father here

65.79.text: would have experienced in Aden in the late 1950s,

70.58.text:
and before him my grandfather 
in the trenches of the First World War.

74.54.text: I knew a few of their letters and photos,

80.78.text: but very few of their stories really.

84.27.text: In fact two weeks after my father died,

86.90.text:
I found a letter written to a good friend
of his and obviously later returned.

93.07.text:
And in this letter it talked about arriving
in Aden, the camp, going out on patrol,

100.56.text: the reasons he had volunteered for a Bren Gun

103.90.text:
and even describing using that Bren Gun in
action for the first time.

109.24.text: Basically all stuff I didn't know.

110.59.text:
And I resolved, strange as it might sound,
to go and experience something very similar.

119.90.text:
And I thought by doing that it might answer
a few questions I was no longer able to ask.

128.26.text:
It took me over a year to organise this trip
to Afghanistan.

133.72.text:
A friend of mine in the Royal Navy had found
me the relevant contacts details

139.62.text:
for the MOD [Ministry of Defence] and eventually 
I was given the green light to go.

145.48.text: I spent a weekend doing pre-deployment training,

149.31.text: learning basics like getting in a helicopter,

153.53.text:
how maybe to get out of a minefield, hostage
situations

158.52.text:
and lots of battlefield medical drills 
of course.

164.31.text:
If you can imagine arriving at Brize Norton
at three in the morning

170.34.text:
and for the first time in your life totally
in a military world.

174.35.text:
I met a guy at the Royal British Legion who
gave me a good piece of advice.

179.31.text:
He said, 'Jules, you'll be feeling nervous,
you'll be out of your depth.

184.49.text: I suggest you get drawing straight away.

187.82.text:
Before you know it you'll begin to get 
a few results and relax.'

190.40.text:
I thought it was a good piece of advice 
and I took it.

194.73.text:
This drawing above here is one of the first
relative successes

203.14.text:
and it was done under the faintest glimmer
of light in a Hercules troop carrier.

209.50.text:
I remember seeing opposite the dark silhouettes
of the troops as they nodded off

217.95.text: and vaguely able to discern the odd feature.

221.57.text:
And I made this series of drawings and at
the time I wondered

226.55.text:
what was going through all the individual
minds of the guys opposite.

230.49.text:
Some were seasoned campaigners; they had done
it all before.

234.12.text: Others were heading off for the first time.

240.23.text:
Arriving in Afghanistan 2 YORKS were based
in a little camp

243.33.text:
called Camp Tombstone inside 
the main Afghan camp, Camp Shorabak,

249.61.text:
and adjacent to Camp Bastion 
which you would have all heard of.

254.39.text:
Their special task was training and leading
the Afghan Army on operations -

263.39.text: I spent the first few days around these bases

267.84.text:
and it gave me a good opportunity to catch
up with myself,

272.26.text:
begin to understand where I was - 
the atmosphere, the context

277.85.text:
and things like armoured vehicles and 
the details of uniforms.

282.47.text:
I was even told about the rank system 
by a sergeant major.

287.24.text: So it was all a big learning curve.

288.92.text:
However, I realised it wasn't just 
a learning curve for me.

295.20.text:
One afternoon I went to draw the sentries
doing stag duties at the main gate.

302.54.text: One sentry - it was his first stag duty,

306.42.text:
and his first tour to Afghanistan - 
he was very nervous.

310.96.text:
And at one point an Afghan vehicle 
approached the gate

316.24.text: and crossed a very strict 'no crossing' line.

320.32.text:
I remember, terrified, he turned to me and
said, 'What do I do?'

326.89.text: And it was a good question.

330.30.text: At this time a large operation was launched

341.23.text:
and it involved 15,000 British, American 
and Afghan troops.

346.75.text:
I attended the eve of battle speech given
by the brigade commander, James Cowan,

356.79.text:
He was piped in to give his 
eve of battle speech

359.24.text:
and I remember listening to the pipes with
the distant blue mountains of Afghanistan,

365.84.text:
thinking how evocative it was and it was like
a strange symbolic echo to the past,

370.60.text:
and perhaps previous British involvements
in Afghanistan.

379.35.text:
With this operation launched, inevitably there
was a lot of activity down on the flight line,

385.96.text: And I spent many hours down there making drawings.

391.28.text:
This one focuses on a Chinook as a column
of troops clambers aboard,

398.54.text:
as if being swallowed by a strange beast that
is then going to take off and disappear

404.37.text:
beyond the sand and 
the storm into the blue sky.

409.15.text:
It held an abstract quality to me because
up until then I had only been in the main bases

416.79.text:
and I wanted to see beyond the wire 
what was outside.

423.31.text: Eventually I did clamber aboard a helicopter.

425.56.text:
I was pulled aside just before I clambered
aboard and shown an important lesson:

432.87.text:
how to use and fire the standard British rifle
if the worst came to the worst.

439.64.text:
Imagine if you can, beyond that wire, the
blue skies, the distant blue mountains,

453.78.text:
the haze in the air and in the middle ground
a fertile green valley through which flows a river.

460.68.text:
And in the foreground a column of troops 
wends its way up to the patrol base.

467.35.text: An officer with an interpreter speaks to a local

472.11.text: and there is a fruit seller on a donkey.

476.16.text:
This stunning setting was what I found 
heading beyond the wire.

481.48.text:
Of course, this is a lithograph done after
the artist, James Atkinson,

487.70.text:
who accompanied the first British expedition
to Afghanistan in 1839.

496.43.text: Except this is exactly what I found.

498.67.text:
And if you were to replace the elephant and
the camel with an armoured vehicle,

504.63.text:
or the red tunics with desert fatigues, 
everything would remain the same.

509.63.text: Now, how did I prepare for my trip to Afghanistan?

515.83.text:
Beyond reading a couple of books and seeing
newspaper articles,

520.05.text:
there wasn't much preparation I could do,
beyond sharpening up my drawing skills.

528.04.text:
I decided I had never been in 
a theatre of war before,

531.54.text:
so it was best not to go with too many 
preconceived ideas of what I should do.

537.83.text:
The idea was to try to be objective 
as possible and, to be honest,

545.33.text:
I wasn't interested in the rights or wrongs
of the war, or the politics.

549.08.text:
My objective was to experience 
and document in a series of drawings

560.97.text:
One preparation I did make was to acquire
an assault vest

564.42.text:
that went over my body armour - 
this green camouflage item.

572.38.text:
We acquired this with the help of a sergeant
from The Royal Anglian Regiment.

576.45.text:
Inside it had large pockets to put my sketch
pads and on the outside,

583.68.text:
where one would usually have 
rifle magazines, as you can see,

588.78.text: I could put my pens and brushes, pencils, etc.

592.84.text:
I'd had enough common sense to realise that
if I needed to move abruptly, quickly,

601.96.text: everything was on me and I could just move.

604.75.text:
I didn't have to fumble around 
with a bag at my feet.

607.85.text: It actually came in useful at the end of my trip.

611.43.text:
I was stuck in Kandahar for three days and
to break up the tedium of that base

618.30.text:
the cookhouse was open 
three times a day for an hour.

623.24.text:
Inevitably I was paranoid about losing my
drawings at this point,

627.92.text:
so three times a day - you were not allowed
a bag in the cookhouse -

633.68.text:
I went through the strange ritual of taking
my drawings from a bag

637.65.text: and putting them inside this assault vest.

640.43.text: And in I wandered, this bulked out figure.

642.77.text:
I received quite a few strange looks as this
strange camouflaged Michelin man wandered in.

655.25.text: This is an example of a fairly early drawing

658.11.text:
and it was done in 
Forward Operating Base Shawqat,

664.41.text:
the headquarters of the 
Grenadier Guards Battle Group.

668.47.text: I had just been off my first helicopter ride

674.65.text:
and a couple of lads told me 
another one was coming in,

676.80.text: if I wanted to get some drawings done.

679.34.text:
I readied myself as it 
dropped out of the sky.

685.27.text: But no one had told me about the downdraught

688.45.text:
and the inevitable wall of dust that would
hit you, and the need to turn and duck.

694.36.text:
Quite literally I was physically picked up
and blown around the corner of a compound.

699.03.text:
My sketch pad flew off in one direction, 
my pen in another

703.28.text:
and I ripped my drawing hand badly 
in the process.

710.21.text:
in fact, this drawing was done 
while the helicopter was on the ground

714.46.text:
and, although lacking in certain details,
I think it captures very much the essence of

723.93.text:
the difficulties for an artist working in
that sort of environment.

728.73.text:
You can see here the ripped page from where
it was blown around the corner

733.11.text: and a blood stain up in the right-hand corner.

735.67.text:
And all across the page is 
the dust of Afghanistan.

740.85.text: So, I think, for me anyway, it captures

745.34.text:
and is a good working example of the rigours
of being in Afghanistan.

755.24.text:
As an artist, to get on in Afghanistan you
had to join in with the banter of the troops.

762.50.text: It worked in two different ways.

766.60.text:
Often you'll be working away and a couple
of British troops would wander up

769.51.text:
and, bearing in mind the macho world, they'd
come and watch you for a while,

775.29.text:
then one would turn, 
look you in the eye and say,

780.60.text:
My three-year-old daughter could do better
than that.'

784.08.text: And I realised what was going on here was

786.01.text:
it didn't really matter whether they liked
the drawing or not,

790.52.text:
they were checking you out, sizing you up,
and seeing how precious you were going to be.

795.97.text:
So, joining in the banter, 
I would look at them and say,

799.79.text:
'You're right, mate. 
But it's not bad for an amateur,'

803.75.text:
or 'You finish it off,' 
or something like that.

808.77.text:
To give you an idea of the power of painting
and drawing and its ability to transcend barriers,

814.64.text: I spent a lot of time at the main gates here,

820.36.text:
drawing the bazaar opposite and the patrols
coming in and out.

824.25.text: And they were guarded by the Afghan Army.

828.29.text:
And unused to the idea of a western artist,
they found it miraculous that as if by magic

835.65.text:
a portrait of their friend would appear on
a blank piece of paper.

839.92.text:
Although language was limited to 
'salaam' [hello] or 'tashakor' [thank you],

848.80.text: they would often laugh and watch as I drew

851.49.text:
and every mark would be accompanied by 
'good' or 'no good'.

858.18.text: So I enjoyed my time with them.

861.40.text:
I moved onto a little patrol base called PB
Chilli in the Nad-e-Ali district.

866.81.text:
It had been decided to head out on a foot
patrol a couple of hours later

873.18.text: and, having a couple of hours to spare,

876.54.text:
I climbed up the nearest 'sangar', 
or watchtower, and made a drawing.

882.95.text:
It was therapeutic really this drawing because, 
feeling a bit nervous,

886.65.text:
it gave me something positive to think about
and channel my thoughts to.

890.96.text:
In fact, this is a painting made from that
original drawing.

898.86.text: And it was a stunning landscape.

900.72.text: In fact, it was a Biblical scene.

904.57.text:
It was like being in another time 
and another age

909.75.text:
with the shepherd and his flock 
in the near ground

911.66.text:
and in the distance the compounds 
and little flashes of colour

918.38.text: as women walked past in their buquras.

924.43.text:
As an extreme contrast to this 
was the darkness of the 'sangar'

931.38.text:
or the General Purpose Machine Gun, 
in the near ground

936.78.text:
with all, of course, 
its dark and sinister connotations.

945.25.text:
Three months earlier five Grenadier Guards
and Royal Military Police

950.62.text:
had been killed by a rogue Afghan at a little
base just down the road.

954.32.text:
Equally, two days before, an IED 
[Improvised Explosive Device] had been found.

961.20.text:
So heading out on the foot patrol the danger
element was very real.

969.38.text:
I was told to stick with the man in front
and whatever happened just to stay with him.

977.31.text:
And as we headed out on foot patrol 
it was the first time

982.99.text:
that I have ever learnt to draw 
and walk at the same time,

988.58.text:
let alone closely following his footsteps,
only too aware to the possibility of IEDs.

997.01.text:
This is an example of one of those drawings
done on the move.

999.70.text:
And, of course, it is very minimal, 
you could say.

1005.06.text:
However, it is amazing how a drawing like
this can convey a lot of information

1012.55.text: and can be used later on for a painting.

1019.13.text:
We walked across fields, through compounds, 
down dusty alleyways.

1026.01.text: Locals would wander out to watch us by.

1029.60.text:
Children would shout 'salaam' 
and it was fabulous really

1034.57.text:
to actually be walking 
in the landscape of Afghanistan -

1038.41.text:
it was like walking in a different age 
and time - and to feel the dust.

1043.32.text: I have put this painting here to show you

1048.24.text:
how this figure is connected 
to the previous drawing

1054.29.text: and really to demonstrate how a final composition

1058.34.text:
might include three or four 
drawings put together.

1061.82.text:
And, of course, back in the studio you have
time to mix up colour as you wish,

1070.84.text:
and generally create the composition that
befits the dialogue you are trying to communicate.

1082.29.text: Helmand at this point was full of extremes.

1084.32.text:
One minute you were waking 
in this stunning landscape,

1088.39.text:
the next you were at a 
repatriation ceremony.

1091.34.text:
There was a procedure called 
Operation MINIMISE

1097.33.text:
which occurred when there was 
a severe casualty or fatality.

1106.15.text:
This procedure, little signs would go up all
around the bases informing you it was on,

1113.13.text: and all communications with the outside world

1115.41.text:
would cease until the next of kin 
had been informed.

1118.32.text:
To give you an idea, this was pretty much
going on all day every day.

1124.24.text:
I got on very well with the sergeant major
from the 2 YORKS

1130.16.text:
and he showed me a Jackal armoured vehicle
that had been blown up by an IED a few days before.

1138.51.text: Half of it had been found over a compound wall.

1143.18.text:
In fact a very good friend of that sergeant
major had been killed in that blast

1151.20.text: and inevitably he was still very raw.

1154.27.text: I did a drawing of that sergeant major

1160.83.text:
and strangely he insisted in sitting in a
similar Jackal armoured vehicle as a backdrop.

1172.13.text:
I moved further north up to 
a place called Musa Qala,

1175.46.text:
it was the headquarters of the 
Household Cavalry Battle Group

1182.27.text:
and the DC, the District Centre, 
had been a thriving hotel -

1186.62.text: I stayed on the second floor for two nights.

1191.75.text:
Except this hotel now was 
the battered burnt-out remains of a building.

1197.95.text:
Clear plastic was used for the windows and
the austere concrete interior was broken up

1203.82.text: with the odd bunk bed, dust and Taleban graffiti.

1209.55.text:
Up on the roof I spent hours 
by the observation post

1213.57.text:
and it commanded fantastic views 
along the wadi

1218.41.text:
and into the mountains and 
the beginning of the Hindu Kush.

1221.99.text:
In fact, this is a little watercolour study
made up there which looks north across the bazaar

1231.20.text:
and up towards Mount Musa Qala, 
or 'Mount Doom' as it was called by the troops.

1237.53.text:
And here is the wadi 
winding its way down south.

1243.21.text:
You could say these landscapes have analogy
to war artists of the past,

1252.49.text:
where artists were required not just to 
document military endeavour and celebrated victories,

1264.77.text:
but were required in a more practical way
to record the topography,

1270.55.text: the lay of the land, and enemy positions.

1277.43.text:
And this was even required into the 
First World War where artists such as Paul Maze,

1285.85.text:
where cameras were very bulky and tricky to
manoeuvre through the trenches,

1291.78.text:
and he would crawl along and make notations
with vital information to head back to HQ.

1300.58.text:
Now opposite the other side of the wadi 
was Roshan Tower

1311.82.text: which was a Russian telecommunications centre.

1316.70.text:
Again it was a stunning landscape and, 
in fact, this is a 10-foot painting

1323.48.text: made from a similar watercolour to the previous one.

1327.46.text:
Now, you could say why didn't I just 
take some photographs.

1333.54.text:
It would have been a lot easier and I could
just done with it.

1337.93.text:
However, in my view, painting and drawing
has a certain immediacy

1342.45.text:
and I think we're so inundated and surrounded
by photography and moving footage -

1352.67.text:
it's on our mobile phones, laptops, television,
magazines, it's everywhere -

1357.64.text:
and I think we're so bombarded 
by it these days

1360.29.text:
that we almost see this graphic footage and
straightaway it has gone,

1364.32.text: it's forgotten as soon as we've seen it.

1366.04.text:
And I think painting and drawing really has
in innate human quality to it

1374.53.text: and it has a tangible physicality and expression.

1377.80.text:
I think it is time-honoured and it speaks
to us in this timeless and direct manner.

1383.35.text:
And I believe personally - I am biased of
course - it provokes a deeper thought process.

1390.28.text:
I have always been very intrigued 
by the Afghans themselves.

1398.62.text:
Possibly I romanticise the Mujahideen 
fighting the Russians as freedom fighters,

1407.60.text: but nonetheless I'm still fascinated by them.

1410.77.text:
So at every point I had, I would make some
studies of them.

1416.83.text:
These were two Pashtuns drawn at the gates
to Forward Operating Base Shawqat.

1423.15.text:
And I was very intrigued by them in their
turbans and their long robes.

1431.00.text:
And their faces were inscrutable and I remember 
thinking I couldn't work them out.

1446.88.text:
Once a week a large market took place in the
wadi at Musa Qala.

1453.45.text:
Hundreds of people would wander in from the
surrounding villages and compounds,

1459.89.text:
here crossing the wadi to 
the market in the middle.

1465.18.text:
And they would meet up to trade in textiles,
carpets, livestock or even just to meet up.

1474.53.text:
It was a fabulous, colourful spectacle and
a vibrant scene

1481.22.text:
and a peaceful respite for everyone, 
however temporary,

1485.93.text:
from the ravages and consequences 
of 30 years of war.

1493.18.text:
As an opposite, on 19 February 2010 
Corporal Dransfield put his kit together

1502.43.text:
in a rather unorthodox 
but nonetheless well-rehearsed manner.

1508.81.text:
Similarly, throughout the base 
similar preparations were made.

1514.32.text:
It had been decided to head off 
on an operation at dawn

1519.53.text:
and throughout the base 
blood groups were taken,

1523.46.text:
rounds counted and an air of anticipation
and excitement pervaded.

1528.72.text:
At dawn I headed off with a 
Fire Support Group from the Household Cavalry

1535.33.text: in a column of Mastiff armoured vehicles.

1540.34.text:
We bumped and jolted our way across 
the terrain to a pre-designated point

1554.59.text:
We were to await the arrival of a foot patrol
further down in the valley

1561.91.text:
and to support them as they cleared compounds 
which were a well-known Taleban area.

1569.35.text:
This, in fact, is a little drawing made of
the FOO on the vehicle -

1577.10.text:
the Forward Observation Officer making his
report with 'Three Nipple Hill' in the distance.

1587.46.text:
As the sun began to rise and the haze cleared, 
various insurgent activity was spotted

1599.11.text: and a Javelin missile was set up on the vehicle.

1604.10.text:
And it was always said with a wry smile that
the price of one Javelin missile

1609.47.text: equated to the price of a Porsche 911.

1615.03.text:
The foot patrol was spotted and 
as it came over a rise,

1620.99.text: unbeknown to the insurgents on the other side,

1623.85.text:
effectively it was a catalyst 
and all hell was let loose.

1628.58.text:
I suddenly found myself 
in amidst a frenetic battle,

1633.97.text:
which could best be described as a sort of
organised chaos.

1638.57.text:
I had to seize the moment and scrawl down
as much information as quickly as I could.

1647.36.text:
I didn't have time to consider whether it
was any good or not,

1651.23.text: just to scrawl down a few marks would suffice,

1655.01.text: in fact resorting to the stick men of my youth.

1665.21.text:
This is a painting made 
from that previous drawing

1667.40.text:
and it was actually acquired by 
the National Army Museum, this one.

1674.87.text:
And very much it is about... 
as the column of troops race across

1681.79.text:
the open ground with the protection 
of the smoke,

1687.70.text:
it struck me, and the muted landscape, 
that it was like

1690.90.text: an abstract red brush stroke across the landscape.

1696.13.text:
Equally, it was like a veil or a metaphor
for protection, with connotations of blood.

1709.29.text:
And, of course, reflected, as you can see
in some of these paintings around the room,

1717.66.text:
the red tunics of uniforms from a different
era and different time.

1723.34.text:
Possibly in the 19th century a patrol had
headed across that very same spot,

1735.38.text:
The battle raged on and sitting on the top
of a Mastiff armoured vehicle

1741.02.text:
I had an old-fashioned general's view 
of the battleground.

1747.49.text:
And having never been in such circumstances, 
it was a really surreal thing.

1755.11.text:
I thought I was on a film set or 
watching a Sunday matinee.

1763.37.text:
So frenetic was it all, 
I didn't have time for any fear.

1766.24.text:
That only kicked in later 
when I considered all the possibilities.

1773.97.text:
This is another painting owned by 
the National Army Museum.

1777.78.text:
Effectively it is made from a few drawings
done at the time,

1786.71.text:
and I have tried to keep the simplicity to
those drawings.

1790.98.text:
It's not about so much absolute detail as
trying to keep the energy

1797.72.text: and convey the atmosphere of that situation.

1801.61.text:
I sat on the vehicle with the gunner, the
squadron corporal major, Sean Fry,

1810.20.text:
from the Household Cavalry and he was firing
at this tree line.

1815.23.text: In the tree line were the Taleban.

1818.53.text:
And in the middle ground the foot patrol raced
from one compound to clear this compound.

1827.52.text: In fact, we were actually fired at

1830.09.text:
and I had to duck below, closely followed
by the gunner, here.

1839.04.text:
And I remember as he ducked down beside me 
he had a vast grin on his face.

1844.74.text:
And I remember thinking how bizarre, 
as if to say what fun he was having.

1851.82.text:
Equally, I remember looking out through the
back doors of the vehicle that were open

1858.11.text:
and in the distance were 
blue mountains like this

1862.79.text:
